TETANUS IMMUNOGLOBULIN

  • Indications and doses
  • Side effects
  • Cautions
  • Handling and storage
  • Medicinal forms

Indications and doses

Post-exposure prophylaxis,

By intramuscular injection

  • For adults
    Initially 250 units, then increased to 500 units, dose is only increased if more than 24 hours have elapsed or there is risk of heavy contamination or following burns.
  • For children
    Initially 250 units, then increased to 500 units, dose is only increased if more than 24 hours have elapsed or there is risk of heavy contamination or following burns.

Treatment of tetanus infection,

By intramuscular injection

  • For adults
    150 units/kg, dose may be given over multiple sites.
  • For children
    150 units/kg, dose may be given over multiple sites.

Known side effects

General side effects

rare: Anaphylaxis, arthralgia in children, buccal ulceration in children, chest tightness in children, dizziness in children, dyspnoea in children, glossitis in children, tremor in children,

notKnown: Facial oedema in children, injection site swelling, pain at injection site,

Cautions regarding administration

  • IgA deficiency
  • interference with live virus vaccines

Advice regarding handling and storage

Care must be taken to store all immunological products under the conditions recommended in the product literature, otherwise the preparation may become ineffective. Refrigerated storage is usually necessary; many immunoglobulins need to be stored at 2–8°C and not allowed to freeze. Immunoglobulins should be protected from light. Opened multidose vials must be used within the period recommended in the product literature.

Prepared medicinal forms of TETANUS IMMUNOGLOBULIN

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Solution for injection
